SchwurblerControlllers  1.0.0
The german foto podcast legend Happy Shooting had a discussion about Midi controller for Lightroom. One comment on the website and voila a new project is born. This project will (hopefully) contain everything from zero to hero to get create your own customized Midi Controller for Lightroom. It is completly community driven, so everyone is allowed to contribute. And it's not intended to earn money with it. Just from the community for the community. In general you might even need no case, just the pcb with the solded parts. so you will get an extra small extra lightwight device. If that's the thing for you we might even go the capacitive way and reduce the soldered components and weight to a minimum.
  • examples
  • ControlButton

34 #include <ControlButton.h>
35 
36 // Lets have a pointable uninitialized pointer for our Buttoncontroller
37 // we eill use it later to create and interact with the buttons
38 // @see ButtonController
39 // e.g. ButtonController* buttonController;
40 // If the define configurations will be used the Controller can be initialized directly
41 ButtonController *buttonController = new ButtonController;
42 
43 // This MIDI_CREATE_INSTANCE createds an instance of usbMIDI
44 MIDI_CREATE_INSTANCE(HardwareSerial, Serial2, MIDI);
45 
46 // Having the values for the velocity the midi event will trigger on button push
47 // and the Midichannel defined as constant is the way to to go as we are using
48 // them in the Midi and Controller functions
49 const int kOnVelocity = Schwurbler_DEF_ButtonController_TriggerVelocity;
50 const int kMidiChannel = Schwurbler_DEF_SendTo_MidiChannel;
51 
52 // The implementation of the Midi send function fom usbMidi that will be linked
53 // as callback to the controller
54 // @param int inControlNumber describes the Midi Key to send
55 // @param bool isActive desctibes if it's the push or release event
56 void sendMidiTrigger(int inControlNumber, bool isActive) {
57  if (isActive) {
58  usbMIDI.sendNoteOn(inControlNumber, kOnVelocity, kMidiChannel);
59  } else {
60  usbMIDI.sendNoteOff(inControlNumber, 0, kMidiChannel);
61  }
62  if (isActive) {
63  Serial.println((String) "Function sendMidiTrigger called with " +
64  inControlNumber + " ACTIVE");
65  } else {
66  Serial.println((String) "Function sendMidiTrigger called with " +
67  inControlNumber + " INACTIVE");
68  }
69 }
70 
71 void setup() {
72  // As normal when communicating with Midi we have to define the
73  // MidiChannel we want to speak with
74  MIDI.begin(kMidiChannel);
75  // As we don't have a Midi Thru we turn it off
76  MIDI.turnThruOff();
77 
78  if (!Serial) {
79  Serial.begin(57600);
80  }
81 
82  // Inside the setup loop we need to initialize an instance
83  // ButtonController needs to know the amount of buttons to be
84  // initialized as first param, as second param an int list matching the
85  // midi Keys and an int list matching the pins they are connected to
86  // the midi keys will be matched 1:1 to the pins respecting the order in
87  // the list
88  // buttonController = new ButtonController(3,
89  // {0, 1, 2},
90  // {1, 2, 3});
91 
92  // As the Buttoncontoller are all digitalpins we need to set them to
93  // INPUT, better INPUT_PULLUP
94  for (int controllerID = 0; controllerID < buttonController->getAmount();
95  controllerID++) {
96  pinMode(buttonController->getPin(controllerID), INPUT_PULLUP);
97  }
98 
99  // As last part of the setup we need to invoke the SendMidi funtion
100  // as callback into the controller
101  buttonController->handleMidiTriggerCallback(&sendMidiTrigger);
102 }
103 
104 void loop() {
105  // In the loop we just need to run getData on the controller
106  // The rest is done by the Controller
107  buttonController->getData();
108 
109  // We need to read usbMidi otherwise its going crazy
110  while (usbMIDI.read()) {
111  } // ignore incoming messages
112 }
